description: A Cornet whose pipes are mounted on their own chest located above the main chest in order to economize on space. It was usually of short compass, upwards from middle c on old English organs, and from tenor C on German organs. In the classical French organ Cornets were sometimes mounted, but were not so named.
examplesDescription: Osiris contains ten examples, all of V ranks except for one of IV ranks and one of XII ranks.

examples.name: Mounted Cornet V, Great; All Saints, Edmonton, England; unknown 1772. (This stop is no longer extant.)
Mounted Cornet V, Great; Greene Memorial United Methodist Church, Roanoke, Virginia, USA; Skinner 1926.
